title: 103_hr2901
content: Section 1 amends Section 3553(a)(4) of title 18, United States Code, regarding sentencing guidelines. Section 2 makes a technical amendment to mandatory conditions of probation. SEC. 2 amends Section 3563(a)(3) of title 18, US Code by changing the wording from "possess illegal controlled substances" to "unlawfully possess a controlled substance". Section 3565(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow for resentencing under subchapter A. Section 3565(b) is amended to include mandatory revocation for possession of controlled substances or firearms. If a defendant violates probation by possessing a firearm or refusing drug testing, the court will revoke probation and impose a new sentence including imprisonment. SEC. 4. SUPERVISED RELEASE AFTER IMPRISONMENT. Section 3583 of title 18, United States Code is amended to allow for the revocation of supervised release and require the defendant to serve time in prison without credit for time previously served on postrelease supervision. The amendment to Section 3583 of title 18, United States Code allows for the revocation of supervised release if a defendant violates a condition, with specific prison terms based on the felony classification of the offense. Mandatory revocation is also specified for possession of a controlled substance or firearm, or refusal to comply with drug testing. The court may revoke supervised release if the defendant violates conditions such as possessing a firearm or refusing drug testing, leading to imprisonment not exceeding the maximum authorized term. Following revocation, the court may impose supervised release if the imprisonment term is less than the maximum allowed. The court has the authority to revoke supervised release if the defendant violates conditions, leading to imprisonment not exceeding the maximum term. After revocation, the court can impose supervised release if the imprisonment term is less than the maximum allowed. The length of supervised release should not exceed the authorized term for the offense, minus any imprisonment served for violation. The court can extend the revocation period beyond the expiration of supervised release for necessary adjudication.
